abstract: Government Accountability Office study on 5-year-old slaughtering ban of domestic horses finds that as market for unwanted horses shrinks, more are being neglected and abandoned, and roughly the same number, nearly 140,000 a year, are being killed after journey across the Mexican and Canadian borders; suggests ban has not improved horses' lives, but instead has breathed new life into longstanding battle over whether to allow resumption of domestic horse slaughter, or alternatively, to prohibit the animals from being shipped abroad for their meat.
snippet: A new government study raises questions about whether horses have been helped by a federal policy that led to the closure of slaughterhouses for horses.
lead_paragraph: A new government study raises questions about whether horses have been helped by a federal policy that led to the closure of slaughterhouses for horses.

headline.main: Slaughter of Horses Goes On, Just Not in U.S.
headline.print_headline: Slaughter of Horses Goes On, Just Not in U.S.
headline.seo: Horse Slaughter, Stopped in U.S., Moves Across Borders
